list_definition.definition: to move backwards or in the opposite direction to normal

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He reversed (the car) into the garage
He reversed the film through the projector.

list_definition.definition: to put into the opposite position, state, order etc

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: This jacket can be reversed (= worn inside out).

list_definition.definition: to change (a decision, policy etc) to the exact opposite

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The man was found guilty, but the judges in the appeal court reversed the decision.
‘Are you hungry?’ ‘Quite the reverse – I’ve eaten far too much!’
I take the reverse point of view.

list_definition.definition: a defeat; a piece of bad luck
(a mechanism eg one of the gears of a car etc which makes something move in) a backwards direction or a direction opposite to normal

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He put the car into reverse

list_definition.definition: (also adjective) (of) the back of a coin, medal etc

list_ex_of_english: The effect of syllable length on tokens in onsets and in codas was reversed when we considered the effect of ordinal syllable position on deletion.
Another quarter were shown the pictures in this same order, but the right-left positions of the pictures in each set were reversed.
The values of these response categories were reversed for the positive affect items.
The population decline that accompanied the colonial conquest was not reversed until then.
The children were significantly worse at identifying words that had their metrical stress pattern reversed than words that were mispronounced in other ways.
Despite the admonitions of progressive welfare reformers, it seems unlikely that this policy will be reversed.
Finally, identical results were obtained when the deactivation protocol order was reversed (right, bilateral, then left).
The map g does so in either an orientation-preserving or orientation reversing way.
